direction.raw_text: Rev. 4/2/87 Rev. 4/15/87 Rev. 4/20/87 Rev. 4/23/87 EXT. WALL STREET - EARLY MORNING FADE IN. THE STREET. The most famous third of a mile in the world. Towering landmark structures nearly blot out the dreary grey flannel sky. The morning rush hour crowds swarm through the dark, narrow streets like mice in a maze, all in pursuit of one thing: MONEY... CREDITS RUN.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We hear the ROAR of the trains pulling out of the station. Blurred faces, bodies, suits, hats, attache cases float into view pressed like sardines against the sides of a door which now open, releasing an outward velocity of anger and greed, one of them BUD FOX.

A second Secretary and sometimes Natalie exit and enter with various messages written on a piece of paper, indicating a waiting party on the phone. Gekko often shakes his head "no".

direction.raw_text: You want one more chance? Then stop sending me information and start getting me some. Get dressed, I'll show you my charts.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cruising up Park Avenue. A panel slides open next to the bar with a portable computer on it. A television is turned on to the evening news, a low hum of voices. Gekko punches into the keyboard of the computer. A name appears an the screen...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: with curriculum vitae following; address, phones, businesses...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Know the name?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: 'Course. Larry Wildman. One of the first raiders.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sir Larry Wildman. Like all Brits he thinks he was born with a better pot to piss in... bribed an old secretary of mine to open bar mouth and stole RDL Pharmaceuticals right out from under me. Wildman the white knight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I remember that deal. You were involved? Gekko shuts off the computer and slides it back into the housing, his eyes taking in the low-volume news.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Revenge is a dish best served cold... well, it's payback time, sport. (looking out suddenly) ... see that building? I bought into it ten years ago. It was my first real estate deal. I sold it a couple of years later and made an $800,000 dollar profit. It was better than sex. At that time I thought that was all tne money in the world... (drinks) Now, it's a day's pay ... I had a mole in Wildman's employ. Gave me half the picture, then he got fired...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't understand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wildman's in town. He just became an American citizen. Something big's about to go down. I want to know where he goes and who he sees. I want you, sport, to give me the missing half of the picture...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Follow him? Mr. Gekko I... (shaken) It's not what I do. I could lose my license. If the SEC found out, I could go to jail. It's inside information, isn't it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Inside information. Oh you mean like when a father tells his son about a court ruling on an airline? Or someone overhears me saying I'm gonna buy Teldar Paper? Or the chairman of the board of XYZ suddenly knows it's time to blow out XYZ. You mean that? (a piercing look) I'm afraid sport, unless you got a father on the board of directors of another company, you and I are gonna have a hard time doing any business... Bud downs the rest of his drink, upset by the darkening mood. There's something very powerful and frighteninq about Gekko.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What about hard work?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What about it? You work hard. I'll bet you stayed up all night analyzing that dog you bought. And where'd it get you?... my father worked hard too like an elephant pushing electrical supplies. And he dropped dead at 49 with a heart attack and a tax bill and the bank pissed on his grave and took the house; my mom ended up working in a dish factory... Wake up pal, if you're not inside you're outside. And I'm not talking a $200,000 a year working Wall Street stiff flying first class and being "comfortable", I'm talking rich pal, rich enough to fly in your own jet, rich enough not to waste time,
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: million, a player Bud -- or nothing. You had what it takes to let through my door. Next question: You got what it takes to stay...?? The car stopping in traffic. Horns honking.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look out there...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: -- a STREET CORNER. A richly dressed EXECUTIVE stands at the curb next to the BUM with a shopping cart filled with garbage.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You really think the difference 'tween this guy and that guy is luck? Mohammed, pull over. The car pulls over. Gekko checks his watch, pulls out the telephone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...when it comes to money, sport, everybody's of the same religion. Or should be... Hope you don't mind if I let you off here, I'm late for a meeting. Good bye, nice knowing you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The CHAUFFEUR lets Bud out the door... Bud looks back at Gekko.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All right, Mr. Gekko...you got me. His eyes telling us he is weighed down by chains of guilt. Gekko smiles, gazes at the twilight skyline, a sudden look of contentment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah, it's a beautiful night. I love this hot stinkin' city. (pointing up Park Avenue) ... nothing else like it in the world. Seven million people living on each other's heads, kids born, millionaires dying, people praying, junkies, whores, wills, lawyers, deals, parties, sex... guys like you sport -- dreaming about the big score. You know the best thing about New York is everything you can do here. And the worst thing is everything you can't do here... He shuts the door. Bud watches as the limo drives off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bud, in a suit, waits next to a motorcycle across from one of the most desirable addresses in New York. The Doorman rushes to open the door under the canopy as a tall strong man in his fifties emerges with a LAWYER TYPE and a FEMALE EXECUTIVE. The man is SIR LAWRENCE WILDMAN and his manner and gait convey the impression of an authoritative presence with little patience as the chauffeur opens the door and he slides into the back seat of the limo. Buddy, astride Marv's Kawasaki 500, hits the streets after him. The music through the following Montage should suggest a chase brio.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bud shooting past the Trinity Church structure... Wildman gets out of his limo with his people, strides into the lobby. Bud quickly parks his bike on the sidewalk and rushes in after them... not a second too late.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bud just manages squeeze in the elevator with Wildman and crew -- and -- a couple of other early birds -- as the doors close.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bud eyeing Wildman, looks away as Wildman looks back at him, an edge of defiance to him, why are you staring at me? Not the world's most likeable personality.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The doors open and Wildman and Co. step out into the reception area of Kahn, Seidelman... The doors close and Buddy continues upward.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The street now jammed with people hurrying to work. Buddy paces the curb, reacting when Wildman walks out, saying goodbye to the female executive and getting in the limo with his lawyer... Buddy follows.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Formal French haute cuisine. Power lunches in progress. As Wildman is seated with several well-dressed BANKERS at a good table, Bud tries to wrangle a table (next to Mr. Wildman on top of everything from a stiff looking Maitre d' who shakes his head, barely concealing his attitude towards Buddy's youth and general demeanor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Buddy waits outside, bored, as Wildman steps out, shakes hands with the bankers... Bud making an entry into his notebook like any good spy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Music rising to triumphant proportions. AERIAL SHOT of Limo emerging from the tunnel and onto the Long Island Expressway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: picking up Buddy on the Kawasaki, darting through lanes, staying several car lengths behind.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Limo winds its way along the perimeter road, past commercial airliners. It takes the turnoff for Butler Aviation. Buddy exits the ramp shortly after them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A corporate saberliner jet, its engines running, idles at the end of the taxiway. The limo pulls up along the tarmac next to it and Wildman steps out, walking past a MECHANIC to the stairs of the plane. A STEWARDESS waits for him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bud watches, wondering what to do as the plane taxies down the runway. He spots the flight mechanic and the answer comes to him. He starts running towards the mechanic.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bud races up to the mechanic.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh shit, don't tell me Mr. Wildman was on board that plane? (the mechanic nods) My boss is gonna kill me. I was supposed to give him this. (holding his notebook) You know where that plane is going?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Erie, Pennsylvania...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (into phone, proudly) ...after spending the morning at Kahn, Seidelman -- on the 14th floor, the junk bond department -- where Shane Mora works -- he had lunch at La Cirque with a group of well-dressed heavyset bean- counters... (Gekko voice back: "the adjectives are redundant, sport") ...he later stopped off at Morgan. I'd say from all the palm-pressing and sweet smiling going on that Larry got some nice fat financing... G.G.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Alex and Susan are with him. Gekko playing the computer, eyes lighting up on the phone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...bright but not bright enough, Sherlock, roll the dice and play a little monopoly... what box would Sir Lawrence land on in Erie, Pennsylvania?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bud slapping his face, realizing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jesus Christ, he's buying Anacott Steel!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gordon already has the closing figures punched up on his quotron. Calls his shot.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: When the market opens tomorrow, buy five thousand March fifty calls. You hear me? Start buying ten thousand share blocks and take it up to fifty dollars. When it reaches fifty, you can let out a little taste to your friends. Then call this number -- 555-7617: tell the man "blue horseshoe loves Anacott Steel..." You scored, Buddy! Be in touch. (hangs up) He hangs up, looks at Alex and Susan.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Start buying Anacott Steel all over the board.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A large company banner hangs from the rafters: "Bluestar - The Vision Goes On." Buddy's father, Carl, Charley Dent and Dominick Amato are changing the generator on a 727. A welder is repairing a wing seam. Buddy shouting to his Dad over the noise.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey Dad!... Hi ya Charlie... Dominick... They wave back, Carl climbing down a maintenance stand... lights up a cigarette.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What brings you out here...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Client. Got a private jet over at Butler Aviation... Dad, you always gotta light up when you see me, it's the...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't start, alright.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Alright. Why so pissed?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Goddamn fare wars are murdering us. Had to lay off five guys. Nothing I could do. What is it... money? Bud takes out his wallet, smiles, peels out 10 $100 bills.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah, it is. In fact I'm doing great. New client. Whole new league. It's starting to happen Dad. The Big Leagues! You know what I'm saying. He sticks the cash in his hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sure...lots of guys at the track talk like that... but how do you know you'll have any dough next month... (looking at the money) What's this? I gave you two hundred.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dividend. I figure I owe you about five thousand in nickels and dimes...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...don't be crazy. Put it to your school loans.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't worry about the loans. I'm doing good Dad and it's gonna stay that way now... least buy yourself a new suit.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do I need a fancy suit for. I don't hobnob with the jet set. I just fix their planes. Buddy forces the money into his hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...then buy yourself a decent bowling jacket so when you take Mom out you don't look like the Roto Rooter man. Come on, for godsakes, that's what money's for. Enjoy yourself... Touched, his father shakes his head and smiles. He takes it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Problem with money is you never have enough or you got too much -- and when you got it you're never happy 'cause somebody's always trying to take it away from you. Money's one giant pain in the ass y'ask me... thanks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... Dad, you should've been a CEO. How about dinner?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Whatever night you like.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wait... next week's booked. Let me check with my girl and get back to you on Monday.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah, you do that huckleberry. I'll still be here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...gotta run Dad. You stop smoking, you hear?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bud silent, an intent look on his face, gazing up at the digital clock... as it flicks to 9:30... post time. Tickers, squawk boxes and shouting erupt. Bud calls in his order: "10,000 AN STL 46... and let me know how the options are opening." Music skips along in a revolving madcap fashion.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: hands the buy order to the FLOOR MANAGER. He starts writing a ticket as we pull back:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Company floor traders are jammed into a narrow booth, frantically takinq orders over phones and telex machines. The FLOOR MANAGER gives the ticket to a RUNNER, a young man wearing worn sneakers, who dashes off. We follow him across the scruffy Exchange Floor, as he weaves through a crush of traders crammed around horseshoe-shaped kiosks, cathode-ray tubes slung above them, displaying the latest prices in bright, green letters and numbers. Intermittent shrieks and howls, calls to buy and sell, issue from the far reaches of the labyrinthian room. As in the final leg of a relay race, the RUNNER hands the ticket off to a COMPANY TRADER, who is buying and selling at the post where Anacott Steel is traded. The TRADER checks the ticket and turns to the SPECIALIST, executing the order. The camera moves up as the Anacott Steel (AN STL) quote flashes across the broad tape -- as the price ticks up from
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bud paces nervously at his desk, looking at his quotron. AN STL appears on the screen, now up to 47. Bud puts in another order.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The SAME RUNNER races over, handing Bud's next TICKET to the
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Tilt up to the broad tape. As ANACOTT STEEL, AN STL, rises to 48 1/8.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: On Bud, eating a sandwich, eyes glued to the ticker. AN STL has climbed to 48 3/4. Marv stalks by, shouting on the phone. Bud looks away from the ticker, pretending to read a report. When Marv disappears, Bud hastily calls in at 49.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: On the tired RUNNER dodging through the crowd, and over to the TRADER handing him a new ticket.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Close on the OFFICE TICKER -- as Anacott Steel hits 50. Buddy jumps up from his chair, and animatedly crosses to Marv who is on the phone, cold calling.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tell Mr. Ehrlich I've got important financial news! It concerns his future. Bud presses down on the phone button, cutting him off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What the hell...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anacott Steel. Buy it. Marv looks at Joe and sees a look on his face that he's never seen before.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anacott Steel -- right. Bud leaves, Marv re-dials.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dr. Beltzer, you're gonna love this! Lou Mannheim hangs up the phone, a troubled look. Bud leans into his office.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Mannheim, got a sure thing. (whispering) Anacott Steel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No such thing Bud - 'cept death and taxes. Not a good company anymore, no fundamentals. What's going on Bud? Do you know something? (Bud uncomfortable, Lou reads it) Remember there're no short cuts son, quick buck artists come and go with every bull market but the steady players make it through the bear markets. (Bud anxious to go) You're part of something here, Bud. The money you make for people creates science and research jobs. Don't sell that out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're right, Mr. Mannheim, but you gotta get to the big time first, then you can be a pillar and do good things.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Can't get a little bit pregnant, Bud.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's a winner Mr. Mannheim, trust me -- buy. (exits) Charlie Cushing's on the phone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gotcha baby, its do-able... meet you at the Wyatt Club... 3pm Dinner Thursday... Indochina. Then we'll kamikaze down to Nell's, chase a little cotton underwear--I know this 18 year old bimbo, man... you can take it to the bank... (hangs up)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wanna play some tennis Saturday?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You mean teach you how to play. Can't. Going fly fishing in Canada, big client...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...you take that Anacott Steel?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...light snack, but good, thanks pal, you're sharking your way up... Dan Steeples's talking confidentially on the phone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've just heard the most lovely two words... 'Anacott Steel.' Buddy dialing the phone number that Gekko gave him. He speaks into the receiver, in a hushed voice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...Blue horseshoe loves Anacott Steel. (hangs up)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The REPORTER on the other end of the phone hangs up. He rises from his desk, strides across the busy news floor, over to an ASSOCIATE.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anacott Steel's in play. Check the arbs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wind and waves. Gekko's modern, Sante Fe structure house sits on a dune overlooking the grey Atlantic.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sweeten the offer, throw 2 bucks more in a convertible preferred. And 5 year contracts for themselves.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Immense slanted ceilings, a vast clean modern space filled with dozens of contemporary art objects, junk sculptures, floor to ceiling windows radiating light, that look out on a cantilevered deck and pool - and the ocean beyond.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... Cromwell wants to play financial chicken with me, we'll see who swerves first. Where the hell's Gene? Gekko slumps down on a sofa, exhausted, watching one of several news reports he master-controls with a remote.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You sent him to Vermont to get the deposition from the CEO Cromwell fired.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...done and done. Night gang, and Susan no legs waving in the air tonight. I want you dreaming about Teldar Paper. During this, RUDY, Gordon's 3 year-old son, drives in in the latest electronic baby toy -- a Porsche-bodied electric car. Gekko hangs up, checks out a Reuters quotron positioned nearby.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rudy Kazootee, how's my cutie! The kid jumps out of the car and scoots into his father's lap.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Daddy bad boy! Bad boy! -- play with Wudi... Now!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, not now Rudy. Daddy's making money to buy you toys. Daddy work.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Daddy work bad boy! Gordon absently tossles Rudy's hair, his eyes glued to the
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . The kid senses it, jumps back off his lap and into the car.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...the big story tonight is Anacott Steel which closed at 51 1/8.  Up 5 1/8 from yesterday's close on heavy trading... Kate, Gordon's beautiful, raven-haired wife, homemaker and antiquer, enters with the bovine-eyed AU PAIR GIRL from France... just at Rudy drives his car into a wall where it stalls, engines grinding.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I think somebody's playing hooky from the bathtub. Rudy, say good night DAddy...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Shut that off, willya! Kate, upset with the noise, tries to pull her son nicely out of the car. The Korean HOUSEBOY coming in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Calls for you, sir, a reporter from Time magazine on two, says it's important... and a Mr. Fox on three.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I come to the country and it's worse than the city! I'm not home... (changes mind, pushes in) Yeah?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Gekko, I've been trying to reach you. We got the options. We got a good execution on them! Meanwhile, the kid has no intention of going anywhere and plants his feet and emits the loudest shrieking this side of the fat lady in the opera.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nicole! Take him will you... Handing the bawling, writhing mass of anger to Nicole as if it were laundry she doesn't want to touch... Nicole takes him screaming out of the room... Gordon trying to concentrate on the TV.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Papers and charts are strewn around, trailing down to a box of take-out pizza and empty beer bottles. Bud has stayed late.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I got all I could get which was
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (almost apologetic, speeding on the high of the buy...)
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: shares plus 5000 March 50 calls. Average price of $47 a share And $4 per contract for the call. I just wish I could've got more.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't expect to get it all, sport, you'll burn out. First rule of business is never get emotional about stock, clouds the judgment. Where do we stand?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In response to an inquiry from the New York Stock Exchange, management issued a terse no comment. Wildman would not return phone calls. Analysts believe the company is worth $75 per share in a transaction.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: John and Carmen are here and the Livingstons are on their way...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll be right there, fix them a drink.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...we have 37.2 million invested. At this point, we're up 3.1 million and some change. If it goes to 75 bucks we can clean close to 12 mill.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're walking between the raindrops kid. I expect Sir Larry is choking on his royal chamber pot by now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My firm needs your signature on these option agreements tonight, sir, otherwise we could take a real bath tomorrow.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...Can't it wait? I'm good for it. (Bud waits, "Sir") ...Awright. Come out, get the directions from Natalie and hurry up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bud's P.O.V. as he pulls up to an austere, ultra- sophisticated monolith of glass and wood dominating a stretch of dune overlooking the Atlantic's angry surf. Several Jags, state of the art Jeeps and a Rolls are drawn up outside. Bud, getting out of his faded Honda, goes up the stairs to the door. He rings several times.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: opens it and looks at Buddy somewhat warily. Laughter and voices are heard from inside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Can I help you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bud Fox. Got some papers for Mr. Gekko to sign.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wait a moment please. Without thinking he closes the door in Joe's face. He stands there, harrassed peering around through a window on the lawn. A small gathering of friends in progress around a glowing fireplace. The butler waves him in from the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bud enters, as Gekko approaches.  He seems annoyed to be disturbed at his country home.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sorry, Mr. Gekko.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Allright. Wait here... About to go when his wife, Kate Gekko, comes over. A pretty dark-haired woman.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Problems?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No... Bud Fox, my wife, Kate... They exchange pleasantries.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You came from the city? (with a look to Gordon) Long drive, have a drink. Gekko doesn't seem to like the idea, but...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah, why not, Bud boy... Kate's walking back inside to her guests, as Bud sidles over to Gekko.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...if you'd rather not, Mr. Gekko, I can leave...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They cross to the main living room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...It's okay Buddy, you know Alex... Candice Rogers. (Alex and his date shake hands, faintly aloof) ...This is Stone Livingston... and his wife Muffie. (a young stuffy banker in weekend corduroys looks at Bud as if he obviously doesn't belong) ...Darien Taylor, Sam Ruspoli, Carmen Winters, Dick Brady... All old friends. Bud looking wide-eyed at the beautiful "Calvados" BLONDE he's been dreaming of for weeks... she's with Mr. GQ and doesn't recognize Bud, nods back, they all nod back, naturally suspicious of the young outsider... Rudy's TOY ROBOT wheels  around the floor with a drink on its tray, talking computer talk...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...good idea Gordon, good help is hard to find these days but can he whip up a dry vodka martini...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...well he doesn't talk back or steal the silver and Dick's gonna get me an exemption on him, aren't you... (Dick Brady is obviously an accountant) Bud plucks a glass of wine from the robot's tray and plunks himself down on a sofa, overhearing the conversation between Muffie Livingston and Candice Rogers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...there I am in St. Kitt's in my new Kamali leopard skin V-cut bikini which is going to turn back the clock on our marriage five years, you know what I mean, and I can't even fit into it, my skin's all pink and inflamed, and I look like a walking social disease all because this Ukranian bitch botched the wax on my bikini line.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh my god, how ghastly, you should sue her... The Korean houseboy has come over to Gekko.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Call for you sir. Sir Larry Wildman, he says it's important... Bud tightens, so does the whole room hearing the name of the moment. Gekko smiles at Buddy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Make Mr. Livingston a martini would you Nyung, and this gentleman... (to Bud) Stick around, this could be fun... He goes to the alcove to take the call.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So, I had to sit around the beach wearing a moo-moo for 10 days, my whole vacation ruined. (noticing as Bud laughs, chokes on the wine, spilling some on the couch) You just spilled your wine. Bud noticing the stain, starts wiping it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're just making it worse.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Larry, what a surprise... (beat) Can it wait till tomorrow. I got some people over. (dryly) ...if you feel that way Larry, come over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The blonde, DARIEN TAYLOR, is examining a modern sculpture as Buddy comes over with two Calvados.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello again, I been holding these drinks for us for the last three weeks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Excuse me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Grand Marnier. A romantic and tragic drink.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh yes, I remember you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Destiny took us apart, but I knew it would bring us back together.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Aha. Poet or philosopher?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stock broker. As in: never have so few done so little for so much. So what do you see in this? Bud indicates the painting in front of them -- a buffalo skull in the desert by Georgia O'Keefe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'd give anything to have this in my house, even for a week.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...few thousand dollars down the drain if you ask me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh really? (looks at him quizically) Well, I guess you can kiss that career as an art appraiser goodbye, because we paid over four hundred thousand for it at the contemporary picture sale last June.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You could have a great beach house for that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sure you could, in Wildwood, New Jersey. If you sold this, (indicates a Rothko hanging near the O'Keefe) you could have a pretty nice penthouse on Fifth. But you wouldn't have much left over for decoration.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Boy, I thought Gordon was a tough businessman, but somebody's really taking him to the cleaners here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not really. I'd say that Gordon is one of the most astute collectors around. He has a great eye and he only buys the best. Like this rug for instance, a silk Tabriz, the finest of its kind. The day after he bought it in London, a dealer representing the Saudi Royal Family offered him twice what he paid. It absolutely makes the room. See how this little bit of celadon in the border is picked up in the cushions oh the sofa... although... (she's really warming up to her subject now) I don't know if I would have used that tea dipped linen for the upholstery - too dingy. And it's a sacrilege having that Pre-Columbian pot in the center of the coffee table. Some dope might use it as an ashtray.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I gather you're a decorator.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You got it, a great spender of other people's money.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, if you're that good, you could probably do wonders at my place.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where is it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Upper West Side.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh really. Home of the exposed brick wall and the (shudders) houseplant.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh it's just a rental. I'm moving to the East Side soon. I've got a couple of deals brewing with Gordon. (shifts uncomfortably with his pretension) but that's just conversation... what about real things? Like dinner. The two of us. Friday. Cafe. Santo Domingo. Bud waits, staring suddenly and deeply into her eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What if I have a previous engagement?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Break it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I guess this must be destiny alright. My first yuppie apartment and... (pats him on the cheek flirtatiously) my first yuppie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You may call me a yuppie... It's Mister Yuppie to you. They both laugh.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So. See you Friday.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You really do believe in destiny?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Only if I want something bad enough. Her date, Mr. GQ, SAMMY RUSPOLI intersects with Kate. A cultivated European air.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...there you go again, Darien, talking with strange men.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's our Darien: elusive, reclusive, exclusive. (to Sam) You know Bud right? He works for Gordon... (Sam nodding, makes conversation, big smile) Sam's in banking. You staying for dinner Bud?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, I'm afraid I've got to get some work... Kate noticing the doorbell ringing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...excuse me. Sam muttering something in Darien's ear of an intimate nature. She glides away with him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Call me next week, I'll give you an estimate... An ironic promise in her eyes... Bud ecstatic inside... looks over, goes to the foyer...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: walks in, his country gentleman clothing somewhat softening his imposing figure but not the cultured rapacious eagle's face. With him a lawyer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Larry, how have you been? Get you a drink?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh fine. Travelling actually. Nothing thank you. Is...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gordon?... He's right here. As Gordon intersects, casually tasting a spot of the dinner.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Larry! Excuse me "sir" Larry, great to see you again, you're looking good. (handshakes)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gordon... (sniffing the guests and furnishings in the room as if they were stale air)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I guess I'll head back...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stick around... Larry, one of my "gang" -- Bud Fox. Pleasantries. Bud nervously shakes hands, sensing Wildman might recognize him from being tailed in the elevator. There indeed is a moment but Wildman's attention blurs as...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Shall we go upstairs?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gordon enters a den lined with old books hunting prints;  he proudly picks up something from his gun collection.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rarest pistol in the world, Larry, a .45 Luger. Only six were ever manufactured.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Congratulations but rarer still is your interest in Anacott Steel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The same interest as yours Larry. Money. I thought it'd be a good investment for my kid...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. This time I'm in for the long term. This is not a liquidation, Gordon. I'm going to turn it around. You're getting a free ride on my tail, mate, and with the dollars you're costing me to buy back the stock, I could modernize the plant. I'm not the only one who pays here Gordon. We're talking about lives and jobs; three and four generations of steel workers... A strong hint of the cockney working class east and London boy whiffing through his speech and manner. The "mate" is tough and to the point but not insulting...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You must be wearing a mask you're laughing so hard behind it Larry. Let's cut the "sir" crap. Correct me if I'm wrong, but when you took
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Electronics, you laid off 8,000 workers, Jessmon Fruit about 6,000, that airline...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I could break you, mate, in two pieces over my knees, you know it, I know it, I could buy you six times ever, I could dump the stock just to burn your ass but I happen to want the company and I want your block of shares. I'm announcing a tender offer at 65 tomorrow, and I'm expecting your commitment. Bud watching this drama unfold. Gekko is about to blow, controls it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Showdowns bore me Larry, neither side wins. You can have the company, in fact it's gonna be fun watching you and your giant ego try to make a horserace out of it... (turns to Bud) What do you think is a fair price for our stock Bud? Bud in the spotlight. The eyes all shift to him -- his moment. After an initial panic, he's cool as a cucumber -- and ruthless as his mentor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The break up value is higher. It's worth 80.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But we don't want to be greedy now, so let's let him have it at $72. His eyes to Wildman who looks at him, cold, icy mean.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're a two bit pirate and a green-mailer, Gekko, nothing more... not only would you sell your mother to make a deal, you'd send her COD... Bud looking sharply as Gekko's eyes flare with hot white anger.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My mail's the same color as yours Larry. Or it was till the Queen started calling you "sir". Now excuse me before I lose my temper... He rises and exits.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: $71... Gekko stops at the door, a beat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Considering you brought my mother into it, $71.50.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Done. You'll hear from my lawyers. 8 a.m. Good night. He walks out with the silent lawyer. Past Gekko who watches. "Ta Ta".
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's right. I had to sell. The key to the game is your capital reserves. You don't have enough, you can't pee in the tall weeds with the big dogs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: "All warfare is based on deception..." Sun Tzu says, If your enemy is superior, evade him, if angry, irritate him, if equally matched, fight... if not, split and reevaluate.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're learning, sport...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Exhausted from the drive back, Bud takes off his sweater and tie and collapses onto the bed, closing his eyes. The phone rings. With a start he wakes and answers it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah?...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The sky is still dark, the first rays of light coming up over the ocean. Gekko, a lonely figure in a windbreaker, restlessly prowls the edge of the beach, waves crashing around him. He's been up all night and has an exhausted, driven look as he whispers over the wind into the cellular phone...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Money never sleeps pal. When I came in in '69, they traded six hours a day, now the clock don't stop, London's deregulated, the Orient is hungrier than us. Just let the money circle the world, sport, buying and selling, and if you're smart it comes back paying. I just made $800,000 in Hong Kong gold. It's been wired to you -- play with it. You done good, but you gotta keep doing good. I showed you how the game works, now school's out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Gekko, I'm there for you 110%.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You don't understand. I want to be surprised...astonish me, sport, new info, don't care where or how you get it, just get it... My wife tells me you put a move on Darien. Here's some inside info for you. That Euroflash GQ guy she's going with's got big bucks but he's putting her feet to sleep. Exit visas are imminent. So don't lose your place in line. (gazing at the surf) Oh, jeez, I wish you could see this. The lights coming up over the water. I've never seen a painting that captures the beauty of the ocean at this moment. (suddenly fatigued) ...an old Russian proverb - "a fisherman always sees another fisherman from afar." I like you sport, I ever tell you that... Gordon, call me Gordon from now on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...Gordon.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah, I'm gonna make you rich, Bud Fox. I'm gonna make you rich enough you can afford a girl like Darien. Remember, power is the best aphrodisiac. This is your wake-up call. Go to work. He lets the phone drop to his side, staring glazed-eyed at the ocean.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: leads Bud into the plush, private office of a cocky young lawyer, ROGER BARNES, about tho same age as Bud, his his feet up on the desk, sleepily waving to Buddy to park his ass... The pictures an his walls and desk indicate a rich family.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fox, Bud D. is this deja vu or has it really been a year. You're not hitting me up for NYU are you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well we're thinking of putting up a statue of you in the subway. I hear you're moving up in the world. An associate already. Not bad. How's Margie?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Can't complain. Got a house in Oyster Bay. Market treating you good? Still seeing that sexy French gal?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nah, she asked the wrong question.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What was that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: "What are you thinking?"...that was it. The hours are hell, but the money's starting to tumble in. I know this guy who's got an iron- clad way to make money, I can't lose and I can't get hurt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So, does "this guy" have a tip for an honest lawyer?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah, check out Teldar Paper, it's still not over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What about you, I hear you guys are handling the Fairchild Foods merger and it may not be going through. Any surprises I haven't read about in the Wall Street Journal?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come on Buddy, you wouldn't want to got me disbarred now would you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who's listening? It's just one college buddy talking to another.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah, right...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Relax, Roger, everybody's doing it but you don't know, you don't know.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...and if I did, what's in it for moi? He obviously has thought about it before. Bud smiles back, nonchalant.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: More money than you ever dreamed, Roger. And the thing is no one gets hurt...how bout a beer?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Too much to do...but I'll walk you out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They walk out past the CLEANING CREWS coming in for the evening, drones of the vacuum cleaners... Bud looks - his POV... A CLEANING WOMAN as she pulls the vacuum cleaner into one of the senior partners offices, the desk crammed with proposals, Bud is lost in thought.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...Get inside my uncle's door Buddy, all the secrets of the world are yours... the life blood of companies, but you gotta go to law school first...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bud comes out of the building and starts walking away. As he passes the freight entrance, Bud abruptly notices a van marked MARSALA MAINTENENCE COMPANY. He looks back, thinks for a moment: a look in his eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bud walks past a row of small warehouses and enters one.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He steps into a shabby reception area. A chain-smoking OLD LADY looks up from the switch-board.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I need to speak to the owner about some business.
direction.name: direction

location: MARSALA MAINTENANCE OFFICE AND GARAGE SERVICE
result.heading: INT.

direction.raw_text: The owner, a GREEK with bushy mustache and hardened face, sits at his desk eating lunch, eyeing Bud suspiciously.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Panos, I've charted the growth of new office space in the city, and I think you're in the right business at the right time.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you for telling me what I already know.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm impressed with your work and I could use a tax break. This is a growing business. Are you interested in some working capital and a partner? Panos puts down his sandwich, measuring Bud.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What makes you think I need a partner?! Bud smiles, ready with his spiel. An elevator opens. A body steps out. A set of keys. Boom up past a clipboard and pen to a shirt pocket with MARSALA MAINTENANCE written on it, up to Bud dressed in janitorial clothing. We move with him to the CREW SUPERVISOR who introduces THREE CLEANING WOMEN who nervously absorb Bud, worried for their jobs. Bud strolls from office to office, looking official, overseeing his crew, making notations on a checklist. Bud slips into the Senior Partners' office, thumbs through a calendar on the desk. Sees the list of people, moves to the computer, punches the client's name in. The code number comes up. Bud nods to a SECURITY GUARD down the hall and enters the file room where he looks at the Cleaning Lady and points to his watch. As she exits, he scrambles nervously through the files -- finds the code number -- then anxiously flips the pages to the critical tender offer document -- with the target name -- INVESTMENT IN RORKER ELECTRONICS CORP. It's stamped "DRAFT" across the page. His face lights up. The secret to the kingdom. He puts it back, exits.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gekko on the phone, smiling.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bud, obviously exhausted from his day and night roles, is telling him something on the phone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bud furtively xeroxes a document on a small hand-carried copy machine in his pocket or photographs it if it is too large.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bud and Alex, Gekko's assistant, having lunch. Alex gives him the briefcase he's carrying. Pan from Alex to Bud back to discover Darien in the next scene.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bud dines with Darien, small talk, intimate looks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bud is in an office, eyes panning the shelves.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Can I help you? Bud's head jerks around. A young female PARALEGAL is burning the midnight oil. She looks at him from behind a stack of briefs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Uh. Wrong office. Sorry...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gekko, Kate, Bud, Darien and A FIFTH PERSON roar over the dunes, each in their own dune buggy, laughing and hollering at one another... Buddy driving right up precariously close on Darien, who screams... Buddy flips over his vehicle... comes up laughing... we sense he is getting wilder now...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Darien rides expertly. A beautiful, immaculately-groomed stallion is being shown to Gekko by the trainer. Bud is sipping wine as he looks on with Kate.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Got him at an auction in Kentucky.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How much?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Close to two million. (Bud whistles) But this sucker can go all the way to Devon and the nationals. Darien rides in, smiling to Bud.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Devon? He looks like Seattle Slew. What about the Triple Crown?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's not a racehorse, Bud, he's a jumper.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How would I know? I once bet a horse. He went out at ten to one and came in at quarter to five. He laughs, a little sloppy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Darien swims in the ocean, long looping athletic strokes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They're finishing lunch by the pool framed by a lush flower garden where Kate and son Rudy play. HAROLD SALT, Gekko's chief lawyer, thick glasses, smart eyes and bags of worry that could only come from watching other people's money, looks very city-like in his clothing, examining his paperwork before passing it to Bud, who is the picture of relaxation.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...You understand Mr. Gekko is constantly barraged with nuisance litigation and IRS audits.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Of course.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...So it's in both our interests to put a safe distance between you and us... (passing a document with a 2nd pen) ...this gives you limited power of attorney for Mr. Gekko's account. Every trade you make is at your discretion. Every ticket you buy must be marked "power of attorney." That means you call the shots and Mr. Gekko has no official knowledge of what stocks you're buying. Sign here and here... Buddy looks, then up to Gekko, who smiles, casual.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...just the beginning, sport, just the begining... Bud smiles, signs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...you understand if any problems arise, you're out there on your own. The trail stops with you...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All's fair in love and war.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The art of which is deception. Spread the buy orders through different accounts and you won't get burned...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I think I got some friends that won't mind making some easy money... As Kate drifts over with Rudy and the French au pair GIRL, NICOLE.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rudy, viens ici, dit bonjour a Monsieur Bud. Rudy either says "No!" or "Bonjour Monsieur Bud!' depending on the mood of the kid. Gordon sweeping him up and playing with him. The kid squeals with glee.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Already speaks a little French, kid got the highest score on his IQ test.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...it's so tough to get into a good nursery school now. They even visit your home to make sure your paintings and furnishings are acceptable.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's it cost these days?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: $5,000 just for the tuition... plus the books and supplies... (with a look to Gordon) ...some parents even have bodyguards. It's not a bad idea... (picking up Rudy) ...now that's it for you with the grown-ups young man. As Rudy smashes the strawberries around his face and resists going. "No! No!" Kate exasperated gives the child to Nicole.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nicole, take him for a nap, please.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He doesn't nap anymore, Madame. It's been...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then play with him till he gets tired. We're going out tonight but we like to see him at, let's see, six; give him a bath and put that cute little black suit on him... (to Bud and Gordon) Black clothes are the newest things, so chic and milk stains, carrot juice stains just don't show up. Kids -- boy, can they take it out of you! Nicole's "Oui, Madame" is lost in the wrestling match she goes through to drag him out screaming. Kate walking off. Harold gives Buddy another piece of paper...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is a contact at one of our banks. On settlement day you'll open an account there for Mr. Gekko under the name of Geneva, Roth Holding Corp. Then you'll wire transfer the money to this account in the Cayman Islands...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Think about incorporating yourself there, Bud, Harold will take care of it for you. (with a look to Harold) ... at a reasonable fee. You're gonna make a lot of money now Bud... stakes are gonna go up, no mistakes...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...piece of cake, Gordon...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The camera glides off some FISHERMEN hauling their catch off their beached boat to Darien who comes tromping out of the surf, water glistening off her lean athletic body. Bud stands before her, cool seductive eyes, holding out a towel. She steps up to him and smiles inscrutably. Takes the towel from him, drying herself, instead.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If I could have anything... this would almost do.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah, almost... Looks at her, stifles his thought.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So, how did your conference go with Gordon?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The conference, oh yeah. Fine. We reached an agreement and decided to divide up the world between us.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You have modest wants. I like that in a man.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And what do you want?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...a Turner, a perfect canary diaiaond... a Lear jet... world peace... the best of everything...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, why stop at that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're not trouble by any chance. Are you? She looks at him, tosses the towel over her shoulder and starts back toward the house. Buddy watches her go.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The annual Teldar Paper stockholders' meeting is in session:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: stockholders are there -- many middle aged and older, one bag lady. Cromwell sits on an elevated platform at the front of the room surrounded by an army of bulky EXECUTIVES, none of them weighing less than 200 pounds, ACCOUNTANTS and
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Gekko in contrast seems like Robin Hood seated with Alex, Harold, Bud and the other stockholders. Cromwell is delivering his prepared attack on Gekko in a highly sarcastic, gruff manner.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...Your company, ladies and gentlemen, is under siege from Gordon Gekko. Teldar Paper is now leveraged to the hilt, like some piss poor South American country...instead of using our cash to build plants, build our business, all this man really wants is to get paid to withdraw his tender offer and that will cost us approximately another $200 million in greenmail which will be passed on to the consumer... Gekko seething, jumps up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where do you get off speaking about me like that, making remarks to the press, I resent these remarks, I demand the right to speak.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sit down, sir, you're out of order, haven't you done enough damage to Teldar as it is?...have you no sense of decency? (to shareholders) How can your management... Gekko is urged to sit down by his people but we hear various catcalls, "Let the man speak!" "Sit down, Gekko!"
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...concentrate on long term growth when we're busy fighting the get- rich-quick, short term profit, slot machine mentality of Wall Street when we should be fighting Japan! The original fundamental reason for Wall Street was to capitalize American business, underwrite new business, build companies, build America. The "deal" has now succeeded goods and services as America's gross national product and in the process, we are undermining our foundation. This cancer is called "greed". Greed and speculation have replaced long-term investment. Corporations are being taken apart like erector sets, without any consideration of the public good. I strongly recommend you to see through Mr. Gekko's shameless intention here to strip this company and severely penalize the stockholders. I strongly recommend you to reject his tender by voting for management's restructuring of the stock.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gekko is now at floor level with a microphone. He's calmer, makes his pitch to the stockholders, looking up at the management.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...I appreciate the chance you're giving me, Mr. Cromwell, as the single largest stockholder in Teldar, to speak. (gets some laughter and applause, loosens) On the way here today I saw a bumper sticker. It said, "Life is a bitch... then you die". (gets another laugh) ...well ladies and gentlemen, we're not here to indulge in fantasies, but in political and economic reality. America has become a second rate power. Our trade deficit and fiscal deficit are at nightmare proportions. In the days of the 'free market' when our country was a top industrial power, there was accountability to the shareholders. The Carnegies, the Mellons, the man who built this industrial empire, made sure of it because it was their money at stake. Today management has no stake in the company. Altogether these guys sitting up there own a total of less than 3% and where does Mr. Cromwell put his million dollar salary? Certainly not in Teldar stock, he owns less than 1%. You own Teldar Paper, the stockholders, and you are being royally screwed over by these bureaucrats with their steak lunches, golf and hunting trips, corporate jets, and golden parachutes! Teldar Paper has 33 different vice presidents each earning over $200,000 a year. I spent two months analyzing what these guys did and I still can't figure it out. (a big laugh) Cromwell is pissed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is an outrage Gekko! You're full of shit!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: One thing I do know is this paper company lost $110 million last year, and I'd bet half of that is in the paperwork going back and forth between all the vice presidents... (increased laughter, he's getting them) The new law of evolution in corporate America seems to be 'survival of the unfittest'. Well in my book, you either do it right or you get eliminated. Teldar Paper is doomed to fail. Its diversification into casualty insurance has not worked. Its crown jewels are its trees, the rest is dross. Through wars, depressions, inflations and deterioration of paper money, trees have always kept their value, but Teldar is chopping them all down. Forests are perishable, forest rights are as important as human rights to this planet, and all the illusory Maginot lines, scorched earth tactics, proxy fights, poison pills, etc. that Mr. Cromwell is going to come up with to prevent people like me from buying Teldar Paper are doomed to fail because the bottom line, ladies and gentlemen, as you very well know, is the only way to stay strong is to create value, that's why you buy stock, to have it go up. If there's any other reason, I've never hear it. (laughter) That's all I'm saying...it's you people who own this company, not them, they work for you and they've done a lousy job of it. Get rid of them fast, before you all get sick and die. I may be an opportunist, but if these clowns did a better job, I'd be out of work. In the last seven deals I've been in, there were 2.3 million stockholders that actually made a pretax profit of $12 billion. When I bought the Ixtlan Corporation it was in the exact same position Teldar is today -- I turned three of its companies private and I sold four others -- and each of these companies, liberated from the suffering conglomerate has prospered. I am not a destroyer of companies, I am a liberator of them. The point is, ladies and gentlemen, greed is good. Greed works, greed is right. Greed clarifies, cuts through, and captures the essence of the evolutionary spirit. Greed in all its forms, greed for life, money, love, knowledge, has marked the upward surge of mankind -- and greed, mark my words -- will save not only Teldar Paper but that other malfunctioning corporation called the USA...Thank you. Much applause as he sits. Now a standing ovation; shouts of approval. Cromwell knows he has lost the day, tries to continue the meeting by calling for "order". Bud watches, impressed.

Darien sitting in a fantastical adirondack chair made from gnarled branches, amused by Bud's reactions to the furniture.

direction.raw_text: - INT. BUD'S CONDO - DAY Bud goes over a stack of bills with something approaching concern as the gothic oak refectory table which seats 20 is carried in, followed by a Jean Michel Basquiat featuring a skull on a rough board. Darien instructs the movers to place an important pair of satinwood Art Deco armchairs upholstered in buttery suede (last Saturday's auction purchase for $20,000) at either end of the titanic sofa. No vestige is left of the cookie cutter space we first saw. Walls have been removed, mouldings and architectural found objects added, imitation rare woods, marbles and frescos have been created from nothing by the magic hands of the tromp l'oeil crew. The point is, decorating can transform.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The look of the place is evocative of ancient times, yet sumptuous. Darien and Bud sink into the bales of down in the sofa and are dwarfed. She rests her head on a hand stencilled velvet Venetian throw pillow, looking like a Pre-Raphaelite madonna. A terracotta pot with a spray of white phaleonopsis graces the coffee table. As the sun sets over the canyons of highrises, Bud walks around his new home totally in awe. This apartment, perfect in its restrained taste with all the "correct" flowers and objects, has nothing to do with him. Perhaps he can understand the state-of-the-art kitchen, the computerized telephone, stereo and light system, but he needs a set of instructions just to be able to switch on David Letterman. This apartment is Darien's fantasy, and Bud is merely the incidental client who paid for it. Most importantly to her, it is ready to be photographed by House and Garden.
